I don't know about any specialities in the src directory.
Note this bug dosen't occur with 3.2M4 but always reproducable with both
3.2M5a and 3.2M6.

I tried it with two CVS servers: CVSNT 2.5.03 and
the built in CVS server under Mandriva Linux 2005 Limited Edition.

I can send you the whole affected CVS project directory structure in a zip file
(it is 957 kB) but please give me a private e-mail address since I don't want to
publish our project in a Bugzilla attachment.
Could you attach your .project file and .classpath file? I suspect the problem occurs becuase some informqation in one of these fils is causing a non-local folder to be created.

Created an attachment (id=37614)
classpath file

Attached the .classpath and .project

Please remember 3.2M4 works correctly.

Thanks for the files. We haven't made any changes to CVS checkout since M4 but I knew there were changes to other areas. I suspect this problem is related to resource linking at arbitrary depths (new since M4). Here is the entry from the .project file that specifies a link.

- <linkedResources>
- <link>
  <name>src/countries.txt</name> 
  <type>1</type> 
  <location>C:/workspace_http/Common/src/countries.txt</location> 
  </link>
  </linkedResources>

John, the specification of the link seems to cause a creation of a non-local folder (I haven't verified this yet but it is the most likely cause). This is breaking CVS which doesn't anticipate the existance of a non-local folder. I could modify CVS to handle the non-local case but I think it would be better if this problem was solved in the Resources plugin.

Exactly, that is the problem. I've removed the entry from the .project file,
committed into CVS, deleted the project and checked it out again. The project can
be checked out now.

There is a small window after the project is created and before the folder is created that a non-local folder was created as a place-holder for the missing parent of the linked resource.  I will fix this in core resources - clients should never see non-local resources unless they have been explicitly created as such.

(For future reference, please attach log files and stack traces using the "Create a New Attachment" link rather than pasting them into a comment. Large comments make the bug harder to read)
